isis.stitle: CF 500, CF 600 Intake Air Distribution/Filtering and Charge Air Cooler - Intake Air Distribution and Filtering - Diagnosis and Testing

svcsubproc.title: Symptom Chart

entry.para: Excessive black smoke under load/low power

item.para: High restriction caused by foreign material blocking air inlet screen.
High restriction caused by the air inlet iced over.
High restriction caused by foreign material blocking the air intake drain tube.
Leaks at air intake joints due to loose clamps or disconnected ducts.
Restriction in the air cleaner element.
Pressurized air leaking from loose connections or cracks in the charge-air-cooler, ducts or intake components.
Leaks or restrictions in the exhaust system will cause the turbine and impeller to operate at a lower speed and reduce the amount of air being forced into the cylinders.
A restriction in the pressure side of the intake air system will change the air-to-fuel ratio.
A malfunctioning or misadjusted turbocharger wastegate can result in low boost pressures.

Failure of the turbocharger internal components. A bearing failure can produce friction, reducing the speed of the rotor assembly. Bearing failure can cause the compressor and impeller blades to rub the housing, reducing the rotor assembly speed.
REMOVE foreign material.
CHECK the air intake pipe. If frozen, carefully thaw out.
REMOVE foreign material.
INSPECT air intake joints. REATTACH ducts and TIGHTEN clamps to specification.
INSTALL a new air cleaner element.

CHECK the entire intake air system for leaks. CARRY OUT the charge-air-cooler leak test. REFER to Leak Test - Charge-Air-Cooler under Charge Air Cooler Repairs within this section. REPAIR the intake air system. TEST the system for normal operation.
REPAIR the exhaust system. REFER to Exhaust System in S07002. TEST the system for normal operation.

CHECK for restricted or leaking charge-air-cooler. CARRY OUT the charge-air-cooler leak test. REFER to Leak Test - Charge-Air-Cooler under Charge Air Cooler Repairs within this section. REPAIR the intake air system. TEST the system for normal operation.
CHECK the turbocharger wastegate function and adjustment. INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.
CARRY OUT the bearing clearance check. INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.
A restricted or damaged oil return passage will cause the turbocharger housing to become pressurized, causing engine oil to migrate past the turbocharger seals.
If there is an excessive amount of engine oil in the turbocharger housing and no other causes are found for the excessive oil consumption.
Excessive crankcase pressure will not allow the oil to drain from the turbocharger. This will load the bearing housing and allow the engine oil to leak past the compressor seals and into the engine.
CLEAN or REPAIR as necessary. RESTORE the vehicle. TEST the system for normal operation.
INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.
REFER to EGES-305, Engine Diagnostics Manual for causes of the excessive blow-by.

Turbocharger wastegate failure or misadjustment can result in excessively high or low boost pressures. Low boost pressures can cause excessive smoke and low power. High boost pressures can cause major engine damage.
Pressurized air leaking from loose connections or cracks in the charge air cooler, ducts or intake manifold runners.
A restriction in the pressure side of the intake air system will change the air-to-fuel ratio.
Leaks or restrictions in the exhaust system will cause the turbine and impeller to operate at a lower speed and reduce the amount of air being forced into the cylinders.
CHECK the turbocharger wastegate function and adjustment. INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.
REFER to Excessive black smoke under load/low power within this symptom chart.

entry.para: A. Leaks in the intake air system.
B. Rattles due to loose air cleaner support brackets.
C. Foreign material in the intake air system.
D. Leaks in the exhaust system.
E. Foreign material in the exhaust system.
F. Foreign material in the turbocharger.
G. Minor nicks or dents in the compressor or turbine wheel.
A. REPAIR or INSTALL new intake air system components as necessary. TIGHTEN the clamps to specification. TEST the system for normal operation.
B. REPAIR or INSTALL new brackets as necessary. TIGHTEN fasteners to specification.
C. CHECK the intake air system for foreign material. CLEAN, REPAIR or INSTALL new intake air system components as necessary. TEST the system for normal operation.
D. REPAIR or INSTALL new exhaust system components as necessary. REFER to Exhaust System in S07002. TEST the system for normal operation.
E. CHECK the exhaust system for foreign material. CLEAN, REPAIR or INSTALL new exhaust system components as necessary. REFER to Exhaust System in S07002. TEST the system for normal operation.
F. CHECK the turbocharger for signs of damage due to rotor assembly damage. INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.
G. INSTALL a new turbocharger as necessary. REFER to EGES-300, Engine Service Manual.

svcsubproc.para: If the problem cannot be diagnosed using the preceding symptom chart, refer to EGES-305, Engine Diagnostics Manual for additional information.
